thread.title: Midnight Oil: Australian rock legends announce 'energetic' 2017 world tour - ABC Online
thread.title_full: Midnight Oil: Australian rock legends announce 'energetic' 2017 world tour - ABC Online

title: Midnight Oil: Australian rock legends announce 'energetic' 2017 world tour - ABC Online
text:
Australian rock legends Midnight Oil have announced their first world tour in two decades, with lead singer Peter Garrett saying the band has never felt "fresher, nastier or sweeter". 
The band will perform at 18 venues around Australia in October and November, including several regional centres. 
Despite wide speculation the band would reform, lead singer Peter Garrett said it was not inevitable. 
"I thought it would be great if it did [happen] but obviously I was involved in other things," he said at the announcement in Sydney this morning. 
"Your musical heart never stops beating even if you're doing other things. 
"We've got such a charted history of making music together and it just feels incredible, walking back into the room." 
The Australian shows will be the climax of a 50-gig The Great Circle 2017 world tour, which will begin in South America in April and also take in the United States, and Europe and New Zealand. 
Midnight Oil's Australian dates include every capital city, as well as shows in Alice Springs, Cairns, Townsville, Rockhampton, the Sunshine Coast, Coffs Harbour, the Hunter Valley, Wodonga, Hanging Rock and Wollongong. Tour will end long hiatus 
Shows have been scarce in the past 15 years, but Garrett said the long absence would not affect their sound. 
"I think we've never felt better, fresher, nastier, sweeter and more energetic," he said. 
The band disbanded in 2002 as Garrett sought to further his political career, although they have gigged since then, including a 2009 Sound Relief concert in Melbourne to raise money for victims of the Black Saturday bushfires. External Link: Midnight Oil Goat Island 
However, Midnight Oil have not performed together since 2010. 
Their most memorable gigs include an intimate 1985 show on Goat Island in Sydney Harbour, to celebrate radio station Triple J's 10th birthday, and the opening ceremony of the 2000 summer Olympics. 
They made headlines that night for donning a now infamous Sorry Suits some seven years before then prime minister Kevin Rudd's apology to the Stolen Generations. 
The statement was part of the band's long history of political activism, with Indigenous and environmental issues particularly prevalent in their music. Midnight Oil tour dates
